results.name: Continued fraction expansion of the Champernowne constant 0.1234567891011121314...
comment: The next term, a(18) = 457540111...783010987 has 166 digits.
a(40) = 445735380...113172423 has 2504 digits. - _Harvey P. Dale_, May 23 2015, index corrected by _M. F. Hasler_, Oct 25 2019
link: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n=0..39 (see the a-file for further terms)
Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n=0..161
H. Havermann, 13522 (less the 3 largest) terms (2 MB file)
J. K. Sikora, Champernowne's Constant CFE Coefficients to HWM #12 (789 MB unzipped)
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Champernowne Constant.
Index entries for continued fractions for constants
example: This is the continued fraction of the number 0.123456789101112131415... whose decimals are obtained by concatenating the base-10 representations of all positive integers.
mathematica: f[0] = 0; f[n_Integer] := 10^(Floor[Log[10, n]] + 1)*f[n - 1] + n; ContinuedFraction[ N[ f[211]/ 10^(Floor[ Log[10, f[211] ]] + 1), Floor[ Log[10, f[211] ]] + 1], 19 ]
program: (PARI) { default(realprecision, 6000); x=0; y=1; d=10.0; e=1.0; n=0; while (y!=x, y=x; n++; if (n==d, d=d*10); e=e*d; x=x+n/e; ); x=contfrac(x); for (n=1, 160, write("b030167.txt", n-1, " ", x[n])); write("b030167.txt", "160 1"); write("b030167.txt", "161 1"); } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Apr 18 2009
